awd_titl_txt: IBSS: The Impact of Foreign Languages on Problem Solving: An Interdisciplinary Study of Language and Society
awd_abstract_narration:
Communication in a foreign language has been shown to strongly affect decision making. As communication and transportation technologies have increasingly "globalized" the world, more people communicate with one another using languages other than their native language, whether in business, politics, or casually. This interdisciplinary research project will use a variety of methods to evaluate the consequences of using a foreign language on individuals and society in a range of different domains. The investigators will assess the effects of foreign languages on strategic risk taking, auction market efficiency, public opinion surveys, creative problem solving, scientific discovery, invention, and entrepreneurship.  The project will enhance basic understanding of the ways that language changes thought and behavior by providing new insights into the pervasive impact of language on intellectual activity, including mechanisms of mind, brain, and social institutions.  As such, the project will make intellectual contributions across a range of the disciplines, including psychology, economics, political science, and sociology.  The project also will have far-reaching social implications. For example, given that about one-half of the internal medicine residents in U.S. hospitals are foreign-born, health-care organizations can more precisely anticipate risk-taking trends among physicians depending on whether or not they use a foreign language professionally. Intelligence communities, diplomats, and businesses will be able to apply project findings strategically in negotiation and problem solving situations with foreign entities.  The project also will help address central societal issues by providing new perspectives with which to assess the value of immigration and the innovation that accompanies it.  With respect to education, the project will provide tools to increase the effectiveness of education and training for bilingual immigrant students and to better anticipate the benefits of bilingual education on performance in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.

This project will focus on the ways through which language changes thought and behavior.  Theories of individual and institutional behavior tend to be based strictly within disciplines and typically ignore the role of language.  This project will transform these approaches by broaching the divide between individual decision makers and institutional behavior.  The investigators will employ a novel interdisciplinary approach that involves collaboration among researchers from psychology, economics, sociology, and political science. They will use experimental methods and surveys to collect behavioral, physiological, and brain activity measures, comparing tasks performed in native and foreign languages. They also will engage in a large-scale, computational investigation of millions of publications and patents to evaluate the consequences of using a foreign language on innovations in science and business.  This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

por.por_cntn:
Hundreds of millions of people around the world use a foreign language routinely to communicate and to engage in business, politics, diplomacy as well as casually connect via social media. As communication and transportation technologies have increasingly globalized the world, more people communicate with one another outside their native language. This project investigated how such use of a foreign language affects the way people think and behave, ranging from issues such as how they evaluate morality, take risks, pass judgment and make decisions. Given the interdisciplinary nature of the project, the research team included investigators from areas such as experimental psychology, sociology, political science and economics. This five-year investigation was conducted with a variety of languages such as English, Spanish, Polish, French, German, Chinese, Hebrew, Korean, and Japanese. In all the experiments, participants were randomly assigned to perform tasks either in their native tongue or a foreign language, and the results consistently showed that the choice of language is consequential. People make systematically different decisions and different judgments when they use a foreign language. 

 

Perhaps the most striking discovery of this project is the impact of language on moral choice. When offered the hypothetical opportunity to save the lives of five people by killing one person, most people refuse and allow the five people to die. Though they understand that five lives is better than one, they are averse to doing it themselves. But they are twice as willing to make a difficult sacrifice when this moral dilemma is presented in a foreign language. A foreign language provides a distance that allows people to make a more calculated moral choice. Similarly, in a related study we found that using a foreign language reduced cheating that would have resulted in financial benefit, presumably because the increased distance reduced the temptation of the possible reward.

 

Working in the intersection of Economics and Psychology we found that language in our studies impacts financial decision making as well. People were more willing to take beneficial risks, defined here as those that would net them more money on average, when the risks were presented in a foreign language compared to their native tongue. This was because they were less afraid of potential losses, which typically prevent such beneficial risk-taking. We also found that in auction settings, bidding in a foreign language led individuals to suffer less from “winners’ curse,” which is the tendency for the winning bidder to bid too high resulting in winning the auction by overpaying. In general, we find that when a decision is impeded by an emotional response, decision making biases are reduced when people use a foreign language.

 

Working in the intersection of Political Science and Psychology we discovered that language is relevant to conflict resolution. We presented Israelis with a blueprint for a peace proposal from a Palestinian delegation, which was written either in their native Hebrew or foreign English. We found that the muted emotional response in a foreign language hindered the peace building process – Israelis across the political spectrum felt less positively about the proposal after reading it in their foreign English which led to less favorable evaluations of the proposed measures.  These findings have important implications for cross-national conflict where parties typically use a lingua franca such as English to communicate throughout the peace building process.

 

Over the five years of the grant, our investigation spanned several more domains with interesting and important results. For example, in the area of mental health we found that the strong stigma associated with mental health treatment among Chinese individuals is less pronounced when they use a foreign language. While the Chinese language connects them to the cultural stigma around mental health treatment, English seemed to provide a release from it, allowing for more permissive attitudes toward getting help. Even memory is affected by the use of language. In the context of eyewitness testimony it is well-known that people tend to confuse misinformation they hear after an event with what they actually witnessed. We discovered that if they are misinformed in a foreign language, it is less likely to affect their memory, allowing them to provide a less corrupted eyewitness testimony.

 

This interdisciplinary project has far reaching societal implications. For example, given that one fifth of health-care personnel in the U.S. are foreign born, health organizations could more precisely anticipate risk-taking trends depending on whether or not physicians use a foreign language professionally. Intelligence communities, diplomats, and businesses could apply these findings strategically in negotiation and problem solving situations with foreign entities. Also, this research relates to central societal issues by providing a new perspective with which to assess the value of immigration and the innovation that accompanies it.
